intro: Sabulina pseudohybrida, commonly known as the sand spurge, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and distinctive floral structures. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in open habitats such as deserts or coastal dunes. It produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, and its leaves are usually narrow and linear. Sabulina pseudohybrida is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient species in harsh environments.
